DOC.HEAD: Soviets Offer Help, Urge Warsaw Pact to Support Romanian Revolt
Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Soviets urging Warsaw Pact allies to aid uprising, supply planes blockaded in Bucharest; Picks up 13th graf, `Gorbachev indicated ...'
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today sent medical supplies to Romania and appealed to its Warsaw Pact allies to help support the uprising against Nicolae Ceausescu, but it appeared to rule out military intervention. The Soviet news agency Tass said wounded Romanians likely will be flown to the Soviet Union for treatment, and it warned that the fighting in Bucharest had endangered the lives of Soviets living in the Romanian capital. ``The first planes with medicines and urgent supplies have already arrived in Bucharest,'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said. ``But they still are being held up in the Bucharest airport, which is blockaded.'' Tass said Gorbachev told the Soviet Parliament that the Soviet government ``had decided to appeal to the governments of the Warsaw Pact states with the aim of coordinated efforts in providing support to the people of Romania.'' The Soviet Red Cross, Ministry of Health and other organizations were working with similar organizations in France and Eastern Europe to provide medicine and specialists, he said. Gorbachev said ``a number of other measures'' were being worked out with Warsaw Pact allies, and that a special working group was monitoring events in Romania. He provided no other details. Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov dismissed talk of sending Soviet troops to Romania to aid the provisional Romanian government that, backed by the army, declared itself in control after Ceausescu fled Bucharest on Friday. ``We have to support them from the point of view of medical help and maybe some other kinds of help, but to bring in forces, I think that's impermissible,'' Ryzhkov said. ``We mustn't repeat mistakes,'' the head of the Soviet government told reporters. ``Not long ago, we re-evaluated the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. That reconsideration was made on Dec. 4, and should we repeat something like that a few days later?'' Romanian TV, in the hands of the rebels, said earlier today that the Soviet Embassy had pledged to send personnel and equipment to aid the uprising. The announcement followed an appeal broadcast by the television from an unidentified army general who urged Moscow to step in because ``terrorist units'' loyal to Ceausescu had sent reinforcements to the capital. Gorbachev indicated his country was just as confused as the rest of the world about the whereabouts of Ceausescu, who had ruled the allied country of 23 million people for nearly a quarter century. Tass said the fighting had put Soviet trade officials and their families living in Bucharest in ``serious danger. ``The Soviet Union cannot remain indifferent to the fate of Soviet citizens and demands that those who have unleashed the above actions, endangering the life of the Soviet people, should immediately stop them,'' Tass said. On Friday, the Soviet Parliament passed a resolution offering ``decisive support for the just cause of the people of Romania.'' Hundreds of people were killed in clashes in Bucharest between the army and police forces that included Ceausescu's personal anti-terrorist squad. Soviet media have aggressively covered the uprising in Romania, providing readers and listeners with startling details of the battle for power. Correspondents of the official Tass news agency have provided vivid eyewitness accounts of the battle between army units supporting the uprising and guard units loyal to Ceausescu. Official television on Friday night showed film of hundreds of thousands of Romanians packed into the squares of downtown Bucharest. Gorbachev has given his blessing to the political reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, where one after another old-style Communist regimes have fallen this year to the forces of democracy. While Ceausescu's Romania remained a part of the Soviet bloc, relations between Gorbachev and Ceausescu were notably cool. They last met early in December in Moscow, when Tass described their meeting in terms that left little doubt about their sharp disagreements.
